rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The preparation of 1,1-Di (4-chlorophenyl)-2,2,2-trichloroethane (DDT) ; The role of hexamine dinitrate in the formation of RDX in the McGill or Ross reaction.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Kinetic studies were made on the condensation of chloral and chlorobenzene in sulfuric acid, to investigate the mechanism of the reaction and to determine optimum conditions for formation of p,p'-DDT. The proportion of p,p'-DDT appearing in the crude product is constant during the progress of a given reaction, and is independent of all factors other than temperature. The intermediate in the formation of p,p'-DDT from chloral and chlorobenzene is 1-(4-chlorophenyl)-2,2,2- trichloroethanol. Unreacted chloral remains after all the DDT is formed when the theoretical amounts of chloral and chlorobenzene are used. Excess chlorobenzene raises the yield of DDT based on chloral. The major side-reaction competing with DDT formation is the sulfonation of chlorobenzene.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetic studies of the nitrolysis of hexamine in acetic acid and in chloroform, and : The detonation velocity of axially cavitated cylinders of cast dina.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Kinetic studies at 1°C and at 30°C show that both solvents have a harmful effect on the reaction rate and on the yield of RDX for a given nitric acid:hexamine ratio below a certain optimum value. At the optimum, however, the maximum yield of 80% is obtained with both solvents at both temperatures. The deleterious effect of acetic acid is of a larger order of magnitude than that of chloroform, and may be explained on the assumptions that the active nitrolyzing agent is nitracidiumion and that acetic acid and nitric acid form a complex which is more highly dissociated at the higher temperature.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Reaction of trichloromethyl-parachlorophenylcarbinal to 1,1-Di (p-chlorphenyl)-2,2,2,-trichloroethane (DDT).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The stability of the intermediate at higher temperatures should be established and correlated with the low yields obtained at high temperatures as a possible reason for the loss in yleld. This could be done by forming the intermediate at low temperatures, after which the reaction would be stirred for a given length of time at high temperatures, and the amount of intermediate meaoured by reacting with chlorobenzene at lower temperatures. The yield obtained would be a measure of the intermediate, plus remaining carbinol, present. Every effort should be made to isolate the intermediate. Two metbods for attempting the isolation may be suggested.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The pyrolysis of 1,1-diphenylethane over bentonite : tertiary mercaptans as modifiers in butadiene-styrene copolymerization.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Tertiary octyl, decyl, dodecyl and hexadecyl mercaptans were investigated as modifiers in the emulsion eo-polymerization of butadiene and styrene. The rate of disappearance of these mercaptans followed a rst-order equation during the first half of the polymerization, in accordance with the theory of chain-transfer mechanism. During the later part of the reaction, a more rapid disappearance rate occurred. The rate of disappearance increased with decreasing chain-length of the mercaptan. The intrinsic viscosities and the molecular weight distribution of polymers obtained at different conversions generally agreed with the activity of each mercaptan as a modifying agent. Values for the regulating index of each mercaptan were calculated.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: War research : A - Thermal decomposition of rossite and picrite in aqueous media. B - Velocity of detonation of tubular dina.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Measurements have been made of detonation velocities with an error not exceeding -0.5 per cent, using a rotating drum camera, in conjunction with a Jones and Lamson comparator. Study of the effect of cavity diameter on the rate of detonation of tubular charges of DINA has shown that with a cavity diameter of 3.2 mm. the detonation is about 4 per cent greater than with solid charges, while with larger diameter cavities there is a steady decrease in velocity of detonation from the value for a 3.2 mm. diameter cavity. tentative explanation, based on sensitization of the explosive inside the cavity, is proposed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mechanism of RDX formation in the Bachmann reaction.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The meehanisn of RDX formation in the Baohm.ann reaction has been investigated. from two distinct not experimental points of view. The first approach was made by substituting amine nitrates for the ammonium nitrate, by withholding the ammonium nitrate and by adding ammonium or amine ni tra tea in the later stages of the reaction. .Ammonium nitrate is not unique in its funtion; nearly all amine nitrates generate some RDX whm substituted for ammonium nitrate in the Bachman reaction, although never in yields greater than one mole per mole of hexamine. The belated addition of an amine nitrate, unlike the belated addition of ammonium nitrate, does not give rise to RDX· These techniques were also applied to a study of the conversion of DNPT to EMX· Here, too, ammonium nitrate is not unique.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Transformation of the steroid molecule to permit the inclusion of isotopic carbon.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The biochemist has been aided greatly in recent years in developing his knowledge of the metabolism of organic and inorganic substances in biological systems through the use of isotopes as tracers. Since the chemical properties of an element are determined solely by the number and distribution of electrons surrounding the nucleus, it is apparent that all isotopes of a given element should behave in an identical manner when participating in a chemical reaction. It is this fact which enables one to use separated isotopes to label a compound and to use it as a tracer in a chemical reaction or biological process.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Rehabilitation : a national, institutional and individual crisis.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The interest in the problem of veteran rehabilitation was derived from the experience gained while working for the National Research Council of Canada, under the direction of Dr. D. Ewen Cameron during 1945 and 1946. The report which was written at that time was entitled Psychological Adjustment of Ex-Service Personnel. Much of the material which has been used in this thesis was gathered for the above mentioned report. However, it was not analysed in respect to the frame of reference used herein. The educational data was not included in the report. Interviews with civilians, student veterans, faculty members, labour leaders, employers, and the leaders of conimimity services were gathered. During 1945, a clipping service was subscribed to which proved to be a very valuable source of infonaation, in studying the extent, development and direction of the national crisis. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Reconstruction (1939-1951) -- Canada.
Canada -- Economic conditions.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Asceptic meningitis due to blood and its breakdown products: an experimental and clinical study.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The neurologist and neurosurgeon are familiar with the aseptic meningitis that follows subarachnoid haemorrhage, whether it be due to intracranial operation, craniocerebral injury, or ruptured or leaking intracranial aneurysm. The aseptic nature, however, often is not assured until the meningitis has uneventfully passed, v\^en the causative agent is attributed then to blood in the subarachnoid space. Of great concern to many neurosurgeons is a recurrent form of aseptic meningitis following certain intracranial procedures. Finlayson and Penfield in 1941 postulated that the cause of this form of meningitis is due to the presence of breakdown products of a blood clot entering the subarachnoid space. They stated that after removal of a neoplasm or atrophic epileptogenic lesion, a blood clot is left behind, which soon undergoes degeneration and liquefaction.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetic studies on the formation and decomposition of hexamethylenetetramine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Hexamethylenetetramine, commonly referred to as hexamine or urotropine, is a compound of very considerable chemical interest, since it contains, potentially at least, the high reduction and condensation reactivity of six formaldehyde molecules together v;ith the extensive combining pov/er of four tertiary amine nitrogens. The structure of this molecule has been the object of much speculation since Butlerov (1) first prepared it in 1859 by the reaction of gaseous ammonia with formaldehyde. The structure suggested by Butlerov for the compound he identified as having the empirical formula C6H12N4. is as follows [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The action of sodium chlorite and chlorine dioxide on phenolic substances related to lignin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1944. the Wood Chemistry Committee of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, Technical Section, recommended a broad research on the action of inorganic halo gen-containing oxidants on wood and its constituents. Sodium chlorite was chosen for early investigation because it promises to be a particularly commercial bleaching agent for pulps, because it had not been extensively studied as an oxidant for the degradation of organic substances and because the literature suggested that it had no effect, or at least a very slight effect, on the holocellulose fraction of wood. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Small electronic regulators.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The past few years have seen many refinements in our electronic equipment; the accuracy and stability, always weak points in such equipment, have been notably improved. This improved performance has required, in many cases, the use of accurate, stable voltages for operating the ecuipment, and, as a result, the use of voltage-regulated aower sources has greatly increased. It has been the authorfs experience, in designing such regulators, that performance was not always as good as had been expected, and it was the desire to resolve some of these anomalies that led to the present investigation.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engieering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Assays of urinary corticoids: a comparison between results of chemical and biological methods.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The experimental data which will be presented consist of estimations on urine samples of normal humans and of patients suffering from a variety of clinical conditions. The urines have been assayed by a biological and by a chemical method, both of which purport to measure substances similar to those isolated from the adrenal cortex. The chief purpose of this undertaking was to define the correlation between the results of the bio as say and chemical assay on each sample of urine. A secondary purpose was to determine the suitability of these methods (particularly the chemical method) for use in hospital laboratories as tools to aid clinicians in their assessment of adrenal cortical function for the diagnosis and management of the individual patients. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of a reflectometer type of standing wave indicator.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the study of the propagation of radio frequency power along a transmission line, one of the most important factors is the manne: in which the voltage and current vary with distance along the line. The theory of voltage and current variation along a radio frequency transmission line has been treated in detail in many texts, (1, 2, 3) and some of the conclusions of particular interest to the subject of this paper will be repeated here. In the installation and use of radio frequency transmission lines the engineer must have means of making accurate measurements of the voltage and current conditions along the line. It is the purpose of this paper to discuss various methods of measurement in use and to present the theory and experimental data on a new type of instrument having distinct advantages for many applications. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The absorption and oxidation of phenothiazine in the sheep.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Phenothiazine (thiodiphenylamine) is one of the most efficient drugs yet discovered for the removal of intestinal worms. It has a low toxicity for the sheep and has proved of great commercial value in the production of wool and mutton. The potential consumption of Australia and New Zealand was estimated by Gordon(63) in 1941, to be 1500 tons per year and the present day consumption on the North American continent is enormous. The value of any anthelmintic must be appraised in terms of the benefit derived by the host from the prevention of parasitic infestation. For instance, no one has shown that adult tapeworms are pathogenic and a drug which removes tapeworms, while of scientific interest, is commercially unimportant. However, many nematode species have been shown to have a harmful effect upon various hosts and a large number of these are removed by phenothiazine.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The recovery of whey proteins by the use of waste sulfite liquor.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: After years of research, whey, a by-product of cheese and casein manufacture, is still, to a large extent, a waste material in Canada. Whey has approximately the following composition: fat .3%, protein .8%, lactose 5.1%, ash .6%, and water 93%. It may be seen that the valuable components of whey constitute a relatively minor portion of the total material. Due to this fact, transportation of whey is a costly item and with cheese factories widely dispersed throughout the country, the accumulation of the liquid at one centre is an expensive proposition.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultulral Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of the Wacouno region, Saguenay county, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis describes the geology of three adjacent map-areas, each of approximately 250 square miles, plus a region of 260 square miles adjacent to the east of these three. Since all these areas are associated with either Wacouno lake or Wacouno river, the entire area mapped will in future be referred to as “The Wacouno Region”. The region lies between 65 and 120 miles north northeast ot Sept-Iles (Seven Islands) a town on the North Shore of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The map areas are aligned in a north-south direction, each straddling the railroad which joins Sept-Iles to the iron ore deposits of Schefferville (Knob Lake). The most southerly area, 65 miles north of the coast, is the Wacouno River Area, bounded by longitudes 65° 40’ and 66° 00’ and by latitudes 51° 00’ and 51° 15’. To the northeast lies the middle map-area, the Wace Lake area, bounded by longitudes 65° 30’ and 65° 50’ and by latitudes 51° 15’ and 51° 30’. Directly to the north is the third map-area, the Mule Lake Area, bounded by the same longitudes as the Waco Lake Area and by latitudes 51° 30’ and 51° 45’. Finally, the fourth area lies adjacent to the eastern boundary of the Waco Lake Area and is bounded by longitudes 65° 15’ and 65° 30’ and by latitudes 51° 08’ and 51° 31’. All these longitudes read west and all the latitudes read north (see Diagram 1).[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Consumer credit, consumer spending policies and their effects upon economic fluctuations.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The consumer is the individual who acts at the end of the economic chain. Land is farmed and mined in order to produce natural resources. Out of these resources industries are created. Some of the products go directly to the consumer, others are transformed into capital goods. The latter serve as materials for further processes of production, the output of which is again divided between capital and consumer goods. In a modern economy this development goes on through many stages which may be called the diversification of production. The final result in all cases is the production of goods and services which can be used in order to satisfy human wants. In other words, all economic activity is directed towards the creation of a supply of economic values which is able to satisfy the demand of the consumers.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
CREDIT.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Surface conductance measurements on pads of fibrous material.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Stream current, permeability and conductance measurements were carried out on cylindrical pads of randomly oriented fibres over a range of electrolyte concentrations and pad compressions. Values of surface conductivity were computed from the conductance data obtained for the different fibres, using an equation which described the complex internal pore structure of the pad. An alternate modal of the electrical double layer was proposed to account for the difference between the experimentally determined values of surface conductivity and those predicted by classical double layer theory. This model was used to calculate approximate values for surface roughness and for the total surface potential of the fibre. An investigation of the low-frequency resistance dispersion effect previously observed in pads of swollen fibres was carried out.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The conversion of carotene to vitamin A in vitro.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Ozonolysls of carotene results in the formation of much larger fragments, and as in other oxidations geronic acid is formed. This acid is also obtained from the ozonolysls of vitamin A, Karrer (30). The mode of attack by ozone appears to be the primary formation of a heterocyclic five membered ring, at one of the double bonds, resembling a peroxide and epioxide. Recently, Hunter and Williams (28) have succeeded in converting carotene to vitamin A aldehyde by the carefully controlled oxidation with hydrogen peroxide, and subsequently converting this to the alcohol by reducing it with aluminium isopropoxide. Their yield (0.5 per cent) would not appear to justify their assumption that two molecules of vitamin A aldehyde are formed from one molecule of carotene.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Parental values towards children’s behaviour.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study is undertaken to explore the values which 110 mothers of varying religious and socio-economic backgrounds assign toward child behaviour and care. Of these mothers 78 participated in Child Study Groups sponsored by the Parent Education Department of the Mental Hygiene Institute in conjunction with the Quebec Federation of Home and School Associations. The remaining 32 mothers never participated in any Child Study Group. These two groups were compared in order to determine the effect of experience in Child Study Groups on parental concepts. The study also seeks to obtain knowledge concerning sources of information most frequently used by mothers and the direct opinion of mothers regarding their conception of the value of Child Study Groups. The data was collected by the use of a Sentence Completion Inventory and by an interview. It was found that the values of mothers who had attended Child Study Groups differed from those who had not attended such groups. There was also an indication that mothers’ values varied according to differences in religious and socio-economic background. Evidence revealed that mothers were helped in their roles as mothers through attendance at Child Study Groups.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Social Work.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in the comparative physiology of trees.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] With these thoughts in mind, the present work on five species of Canadian deciduous trees, which fall into three distinct groups as regards changes in water content, has been undertaken. Microscopic observation and quantitative analysis have both been employed. Particular attention has been directed to the hemicellulose fraction although investigation of the seasonal changes in water content, starch and fat was also undertaken. The literature of a number of authors cited in the historical section of the literature review has not been read by the present writer. The source of this information is indicated in the bibliography after each citation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Trees -- Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Decay of active nitrogen.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Studies of reaction mechanisms involving free atoms began with the classical investigations on the photochemical synthesis of hydrogen chloride, when it was realized that the large quantum yields of this and similar reactions must be the result of some sort of chain mechanism. This concept was extended to reactions of organic compounds by Taylor (l), who suggested that a chain reaction of hydrogen atoms and ethyl radicals could explain quantum yields greater than unity for the mercury photosensitized hydrogenation of ethylene. [...] The abundance of experimental data in many cases admits varied interpretations but the presence of both atoms and molecules in ground and metastable states is fairly definitely indicated. The relative concentrations and chemical reactivities of each are still the object of much research.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Nematodoe parasites of Egyptian rodents.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The entire rodent collection sent to the Institute of Parasitology from Egypt by Dr. R. E. Kuntz and Mr. G. M. Malakatis was made up of Cestodes, Trematodes and Nematodes from ten genera of rodents. This thesis deals with two of these genera of rodents and has for its subject matter the nematode parasites of the house mouse (Mus musculus) and the house rat (Rattus rattus) in Egypt. [...] The study of parasites found in the house mouse and the house rat has more than a purely scientific significance, for the direct association of these rodents with man, his dwellings, and his domesticated animals, gives them a prominence in his economic and public health aspects of life. This prominence is shared by only a few other animals. Not only do rats and mice carry arthropods which serve as vectors of human parasites but also they carry parasites directly to man and his domesticated animals by contamination of food and drink; in fact, they also share certain parasites or very closely related forms with man. Their economic importance is more or less inseparable from the health problems which their closeness to man and his domestic animals brings. A solution of the problems arising from this close association depends in part on a knowledge of the parasites harboured by these rodents. This thesis is concerned with the classification of some of the common nematode parasites found inhabiting the digestive tract of the Egyptian house rats (Rattus rattus) and house mice (mus musculus).
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasitology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The pattern of local public health organization in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The protection of public health is today generally recognized as one of the most important functions of government. Few others are more vital to the welfare of the whole population. The sanitation of the physical environment, the control of communicable infections, the education of the individual in personal hygiene and the organization of medical and nursing services for the early diagnosis and preventive treatment of certain diseases - all these health functions and many more are the concern of the various levels of government in Canada. [...] The purpose of this thesis is to examine and compare the pattern of local public health organization in the various provinces with special reference to problems of provincial-local relations. This involves consideration of the different types of organization, the size of administrative: unite, administrative structure and relationships, methods of financing and the problem of personnel. In order to understand these questions, however, it is necessary to trace briefly the historical factors which have led to the existing local public health structure in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
